description: UI component specifications for LLM context (OpenUI Spec format) - Complete Edition v3.3.0 (46 components, 30 UX Laws) - Enhanced with insights from Shadcn/ui, Material-UI, Chakra UI, Radix UI + Material Design 3 fundamentals + Complete Laws of UX

button.description: Clickable button component for user actions

fullWidth.description: Whether button should take full width of container

input.description: Text input field for user data entry

error.description: Whether input is in error state

card.description: Container component for grouping related content

modal.description: Dialog overlay for focused user interaction

form.description: Form container for user data input

select.description: Dropdown selection for choosing from options

checkbox.description: Checkbox for binary or multiple selections

radio.description: Radio button for single selection from group

wcag_requirements.color_not_only: use icon + text, not color alone

table.description: Tabular data display component for structured information

wcag_requirements.caption: provide <caption> or aria-label
wcag_requirements.responsive: ensure horizontal scroll is keyboard accessible

mobile: Consider card layout for narrow screens

tabs.description: Tabbed interface for switching between content sections

required_attributes: id on all tabs and panels

focus_management.tab_activation: focus moves to newly activated tab

wcag_requirements.panel_labeling: each panel labeled by its tab

design: Use icons with text for clarity
Limit to 5-7 tabs (use dropdown for more)
implementation: Preserve tab state in URL hash
Lazy load tab content when activated
mobile: Use horizontal scroll for many tabs

tooltip.description: Tooltip for additional information on hover/focus

breadcrumb.description: Breadcrumb navigation showing current page location

accordion.description: Vertically stacked collapsible sections for content organization

allowMultiple.description: Allow multiple sections to be expanded simultaneously

avatar.description: User profile image with fallback initials or icon

fallback.description: Initials or icon when image fails

badge.description: Small label for status or count display

popover.description: Floating content panel anchored to trigger

progress.description: Linear progress indicator for task completion

indeterminate.description: Show loading animation without specific progress

slider.description: Input for selecting a value from a range

switch.description: Toggle control for binary on/off states

skeleton.description: Loading placeholder that mimics content shape

accessibility.notes: Should be replaced with actual content once loaded

best_practices: Use for temporary feedback (success, error messages)

calendar.description: Date picker calendar for selecting dates

carousel.description: Slideshow component for cycling through content

wcag_requirements.autoplay_control: must have pause button if autoplay

command.description: Command palette for quick actions (Cmd+K style)

data_table.description: Advanced table with sorting, filtering, and pagination

hover_card.description: Card that appears on hover for previews

accessibility.notes: For sighted mouse users only; ensure content is accessible elsewhere

input_otp.description: One-time password input with separate boxes

styling.typical_style: inline, monospace font, subtle background, border

menubar.description: Horizontal menu bar (File, Edit, View style)

accessibility.notes: Maintain native scroll behavior for assistive tech

sheet.description: Modal sheet sliding from edge (like drawer but for forms)

accessibility.notes: Use aria-live if content will update
Use aria-live="assertive" for urgent messages only

toggle_group.description: Group of toggle buttons (single or multiple selection)

ux_laws.description: Complete Laws of UX - 30 principles organized by category. Source: lawsofux.com by Jon Yablonski

heuristics.description: Mental shortcuts and rules of thumb for decision-making

aesthetic_usability_effect.name: Aesthetic-Usability Effect
aesthetic_usability_effect.statement: Users often perceive aesthetically pleasing design as design that's more usable
implications: Beautiful design creates positive emotional response
Users are more tolerant of minor usability issues in attractive interfaces
Aesthetics can mask usability problems - always test functionality
application: Invest in visual design for first impressions

doherty_threshold.name: Doherty Threshold
doherty_threshold.statement: Productivity soars when a computer and its users interact at a pace (<400ms) that ensures that neither has to wait on the other
implications: Response times under 400ms maintain user flow
Delays break concentration and reduce productivity
Perceived performance is as important as actual performance
application: Use loading indicators for unavoidable delays
Consider skeleton screens for content loading

fitts_law.name: Fitts's Law
fitts_law.statement: The time to acquire a target is a function of the distance to and size of the target
fitts_law.formula: T = a + b * log2(D/W + 1) where D=distance, W=width
implications: Large targets are easier to click/tap
Closer targets are faster to reach
Edge and corner positions are easier (infinite width)
application: Make important buttons larger (min 44x44px touch targets)
Place frequently used actions near edges/corners
Consider thumb zones on mobile devices

hicks_law.name: Hick's Law
hicks_law.statement: The time it takes to make a decision increases with the number and complexity of choices
hicks_law.formula: RT = a + b * log2(n) where n=number of choices
implications: Decision fatigue reduces quality of choices
application: Limit menu options (5-7 max per group)
Break complex tasks into smaller steps

jakobs_law.name: Jakob's Law
jakobs_law.statement: Users spend most of their time on other sites. This means users prefer your site to work the same way as all the other sites they already know
implications: Users bring expectations from other experiences
Innovation should build on conventions, not replace them
application: Place navigation where users expect it
Test with users from your target demographic

millers_law.name: Miller's Law
millers_law.statement: The average person can only keep 7 (plus or minus 2) items in their working memory
application: Limit visible options at any time
Use visual hierarchy to organize information
Provide external memory aids (saved states, history)

occams_razor.name: Occam's Razor
occams_razor.statement: Among competing hypotheses that predict equally well, the one with the fewest assumptions should be selected
implications: Every element should serve a purpose
application: Design is complete when nothing can be removed

pareto_principle.name: Pareto Principle (80/20 Rule)
pareto_principle.statement: For many events, roughly 80% of the effects come from 20% of the causes
implications: A small number of features drive most usage
Not all problems deserve equal attention
application: Identify and optimize the 20% most-used features
Prioritize bug fixes by user impact
Accept that perfection everywhere is inefficient

parkinsons_law.name: Parkinson's Law
parkinsons_law.statement: Any task will inflate until all of the available time is spent
application: Set clear time expectations for tasks
Design for quick wins and early completion

postels_law.name: Postel's Law (Robustness Principle)
postels_law.statement: Be liberal in what you accept, and conservative in what you send
implications: Output should be consistent and predictable
application: Accept multiple date formats in inputs

teslers_law.name: Tesler's Law (Law of Conservation of Complexity)
teslers_law.statement: For any system there is a certain amount of complexity which cannot be reduced
implications: Complexity must exist somewhere in the system
Simplifying UI may shift complexity elsewhere
Some complexity should be absorbed by the system
application: Hide necessary complexity from users when possible
Automate complex decisions with smart defaults
Use progressive disclosure for advanced features
Don't oversimplify to the point of confusion

gestalt_principles.description: Psychological principles of visual perception and grouping

law_of_common_region.name: Law of Common Region
law_of_common_region.statement: Elements tend to be perceived into groups if they are sharing an area with a clearly defined boundary
implications: Borders and backgrounds create visual groups
application: Use cards to group related content
Apply consistent background colors to sections
Use borders to define form field groups
Leverage whitespace as a grouping mechanism

law_of_proximity.name: Law of Proximity
law_of_proximity.statement: Objects that are near, or proximate to each other, tend to be grouped together
application: Group related form fields closer together
Add more space between unrelated sections
Keep labels close to their inputs

law_of_pragnanz.name: Law of Prgnanz (Law of Simplicity)
law_of_pragnanz.statement: People will perceive and interpret ambiguous or complex images as the simplest form possible
implications: Simple shapes are easier to process

law_of_similarity.name: Law of Similarity
law_of_similarity.statement: The human eye tends to perceive similar elements as a complete picture, shape, or group, even if those elements are separated
application: Style all buttons consistently by type
Use color consistently (all links same color)

law_of_uniform_connectedness.name: Law of Uniform Connectedness
law_of_uniform_connectedness.statement: Elements that are visually connected are perceived as more related than elements with no connection
application: Use lines to connect related elements
Use step indicators with connecting lines

cognitive_principles.description: Principles related to memory, attention, and cognitive processing

choice_overload.name: Choice Overload (Paradox of Choice)
choice_overload.statement: The tendency for people to get overwhelmed when they are presented with a large number of options
implications: Too many choices lead to decision paralysis

chunking.name: Chunking
chunking.statement: A process by which individual pieces of information are broken down and then grouped together in a meaningful whole
implications: Grouped information is easier to remember
application: Use headings to create content chunks
Paginate long content into digestible sections

cognitive_bias.name: Cognitive Bias
cognitive_bias.statement: A systematic error of thinking or rationality in judgment that influences our perception of the world and our decision-making ability

common_biases.confirmation_bias: Tendency to favor information that confirms existing beliefs
common_biases.anchoring: Over-reliance on first piece of information encountered
common_biases.bandwagon_effect: Tendency to do/believe things because many others do
common_biases.loss_aversion: Preference to avoid losses over acquiring equivalent gains

cognitive_load.name: Cognitive Load
cognitive_load.statement: The amount of mental resources needed to understand and interact with an interface
implications: Reduce extraneous load through good design

flow.name: Flow
flow.statement: The mental state in which a person performing some activity is fully immersed in a feeling of energized focus, full involvement, and enjoyment
application: Match difficulty to user skill level

goal_gradient_effect.name: Goal-Gradient Effect
goal_gradient_effect.statement: The tendency to approach a goal increases with proximity to the goal
implications: People work harder when close to completion
application: Use progress bars for multi-step processes

mental_model.name: Mental Model
mental_model.statement: A compressed model based on what we think we know about a system and how it works
implications: Models are based on prior experience

selective_attention.name: Selective Attention
selective_attention.statement: The process of focusing our attention only to a subset of stimuli in an environmentusually those related to our goals
application: Consider user goals when prioritizing content

serial_position_effect.name: Serial Position Effect
serial_position_effect.statement: Users have a propensity to best remember the first and last items in a series
application: Place key actions at beginning/end of lists
Put important info first and last

von_restorff_effect.name: Von Restorff Effect (Isolation Effect)
von_restorff_effect.statement: When multiple similar objects are present, the one that differs from the rest is most likely to be remembered
application: Use color to distinguish important items
Don't overuse - everything distinct = nothing distinct

working_memory.name: Working Memory
working_memory.statement: A cognitive system that temporarily holds and manipulates information needed to complete tasks

zeigarnik_effect.name: Zeigarnik Effect
zeigarnik_effect.statement: People remember uncompleted or interrupted tasks better than completed tasks

paradox_of_active_user.name: Paradox of the Active User
paradox_of_active_user.statement: Users never read manuals but start using the software immediately
implications: Users learn by doing, not reading
application: Design for immediate use without instructions
Provide contextual help, not upfront tutorials

additional_principles.description: General UX principles and best practices

peak_end_rule.name: Peak-End Rule
peak_end_rule.statement: People judge an experience largely based on how they felt at its peak and at its end, rather than the total sum or average of every moment
implications: One bad moment can ruin overall perception
application: End experiences on a positive note
Fix pain points that create negative peaks

state_management.avoid: Complex token arrays or expression trees unless necessary
state_management.reason: Simple state reduces bugs and improves maintainability

recommended: Immediate evaluation (two operands at a time)
Or: Shunting-yard algorithm for proper precedence
avoid: Complex token manipulation without clear logic

error_handling.invalid_operation: Clear display or show error message

zero_input_bug.description: Using '0' as sentinel value prevents entering 0
zero_input_bug.good_pattern: Use boolean flag hasInput instead of checking '0'

operator_precedence.solution: Implement proper precedence or evaluate left-to-right with user confirmation

multiple_decimal_points.solution: Track if current number already has decimal point

consecutive_operators.solution: Replace previous operator or show error

equals_after_equals.solution: Repeat last operation or do nothing after first =

required: Button elements (not div) for all calculator buttons

reference_implementations.recommendation: Start with simple approach unless complex expressions explicitly required

data_persistence.data_structure: Array of objects with {id, text, completed, createdAt}

crud_operations.create: Add new todo with unique ID (Date.now() or UUID)
crud_operations.read: Load from localStorage on page load

ui_considerations.keyboard_support: Enter to add todo, Escape to cancel edit
ui_considerations.empty_state: Show message when no todos exist

eval_usage.description: Using eval() for calculations or code execution

string_concatenation_for_numbers.description: Using + for string/number concatenation leading to '5' + 3 = '53'
string_concatenation_for_numbers.solution: Use Number() or parseInt() to convert strings to numbers explicitly

global_variables.description: Polluting global namespace with calculator state
global_variables.solution: Use IIFE or module pattern to encapsulate state

missing_error_handling.description: Not handling edge cases (division by zero, overflow, invalid input)
missing_error_handling.solution: Add explicit error checking and user-friendly error messages

button_sizing.description: Buttons too small for touch interaction
button_sizing.solution: Minimum 44x44px for mobile, larger for desktop

missing_focus_states.description: No visual feedback for keyboard navigation
missing_focus_states.solution: Define :focus styles with visible outline or ring

fixed_layouts_not_responsive.solution: Use relative units (%, em, rem) and media queries

div_buttons.description: Using <div> instead of <button> for calculator buttons
div_buttons.why_bad: Not keyboard accessible, no semantic meaning, breaks accessibility
div_buttons.solution: Always use <button> elements for interactive controls

missing_alt_text.solution: Provide meaningful alt text for all images

missing_labels.solution: Use <label for='...'> or aria-label for all inputs

code_organization.separation_of_concerns: Keep HTML structure, CSS styling, and JS logic separate
code_organization.comments: Comment complex logic, not obvious code
code_organization.functions: Keep functions small and focused (single responsibility)

manual_testing: Test edge cases (0, negative numbers, decimals)

performance.dom_manipulation: Minimize DOM access, batch updates when possible
performance.event_handlers: Use event delegation for multiple similar elements
performance.debouncing: Debounce rapid input events if needed

security.input_validation: Validate and sanitize all user input
security.xss_prevention: Use textContent instead of innerHTML for user input
security.avoid_eval: Never use eval() or Function() with user input

elevation.description: Z-axis depth system using shadows for hierarchy
usage_guidelines: Higher elevation = more important or temporary
Elevation changes on interaction (e.g., hover, focus)
Consistent elevation = same hierarchy level
Never overlap elements with same elevation
Use transitions when changing elevation

implementation_tips.css_variable_approach: Define elevation levels as CSS custom properties

spacing.description: 8dp baseline grid system for consistent spacing
usage_guidelines: Always use multiples of 8dp for main spacing
Use 4dp only for fine-tuning within components
Maintain consistent spacing throughout app
More space = more importance
Group related elements with less space

implementation_tips.css_variable_approach: Define spacing scale as CSS custom properties
implementation_tips.responsive: Consider scaling up spacing on larger screens

shape.description: Corner radius system for consistent rounded corners
usage_guidelines: Consistent shape = same hierarchy level
Larger components = larger radius (generally)
Interactive elements = rounded (feels friendlier)
Use 'full' for truly circular elements only
Consider accessibility: very large radius may hide content

implementation_tips.css_variable_approach: Define shape categories as CSS custom properties
implementation_tips.responsive: Consider using different radii on mobile vs desktop

principles: Entering durations > Exiting durations (entering takes longer)
Use standard easing for most transitions
Motion should feel natural and purposeful

fade_through.description: Current element fades out, new element fades in

shared_axis.description: Elements slide along shared axis (x, y, or z)

container_transform.description: Container morphs between two UI elements
container_transform.usage: List item to detail view, card expansion

usage_guidelines: Use motion to show relationships between elements
Provide visual feedback for user actions
Guide attention with purposeful motion
Reduce motion for accessibility (prefers-reduced-motion)
Test animations on actual devices (performance)

implementation_tips.performance: Use transform and opacity for best performance (GPU-accelerated)

color.note: This is a reference. Actual colors should be defined per project.

primary.description: Main brand color, used for primary actions

secondary.description: Accent color, less prominent than primary

usage_guidelines: Always test color contrast with automated tools
Provide non-color indicators (icons, text) alongside color
Consider color blindness (don't rely on red/green alone)

implementation_tips.css_variable_approach: Define color roles as CSS custom properties
implementation_tips.dark_mode: Define separate color values for dark theme

typography.note: This is a reference. Adjust sizes based on project needs.
usage_guidelines: Use type scale consistently throughout app
Larger text = more emphasis
Limit number of type styles on single screen (3-5 max)
Ensure sufficient line height for readability
Consider responsive scaling on mobile

implementation_tips.css_variable_approach: Define type scale as CSS custom properties
implementation_tips.responsive: Use clamp() for fluid typography: font-size: clamp(14px, 2vw, 16px);

changes: Added 21 new components from shadcn/ui official list
Added 28 additional UX Laws from lawsofux.com (total 30)
Organized UX Laws into categories: heuristics, gestalt, cognitive, principles
